dt: {bc}a state of stupor, unconsciousness, or arrested activity produced by the influence of {a_link|narcotics} or other chemical or physical agents {dx}compare {dxt|nitrogen narcosis||}{/dx}

et: borrowed from New Latin {it}narcōsis,{/it} borrowed from Greek {it}nárkōsis{/it} "benumbing," from {it}narkō-,{/it} variant stem of {it}narkoûn{/it} "to benumb, deaden" (verbal derivative of {it}nárkē{/it} "numbness, lack of sensation," of uncertain origin) + {it}-sis{/it} {et_link|-sis|-sis}

Greek {it}nárkē{/it} has been compared with Old High German {it}in-snerahan{/it} "to tie up (to), link (to)," hypothetically reflecting an Indo-European verbal base {it}*snerk-{/it} "draw together, loop around" (thus {it}Lexikon der indogermanischen Verben,{/it} 2. Auflage, Wiesbaden, 2001; see {et_link|snare:1|snare:1}), but the semantic connection is far from apparent. (The {it}Lexikon{/it} inaccurately translates {it}nárkē{/it} as "Krampf, Lähmung" = "cramp, paralysis.") R. Beekes ({it}Etymological Dictionary of Greek,{/it} Brill, 2009) regards the word as most likely of pre-Greek substratal origin.
shortdef: a state of stupor, unconsciousness, or arrested activity produced by the influence of narcotics or other chemical or physical agents

dt: {bc}a state of euphoria and confusion similar to that of alcohol intoxication which occurs when nitrogen in normal air enters the bloodstream at increased pressure (as in deep-water diving)

shortdef: a state of euphoria and confusion similar to that of alcohol intoxication which occurs when nitrogen in normal air enters the bloodstream at increased pressure (as in deep-water diving) —called also rapture of the deep
